Package org.haldean.chopper

Flies a quadrocopter from an android-based phone.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
Constants Contains package constants
 

Class Summary
ChopperMain Class to launch all component subroutines
ChopperStatus Central "storehouse" for information about the chopper's status--maintains updated sensor readings, gps readings, etc.
Comm Handles connectivity with control server
Guidance Determines motor speeds, based on chopper's status and desired velocity vector.
MakePicture Interfaces with the camera to obtain preview frames and to take high-quality pictures.
Navigation Handles Navigation routines; calculates next target velocity vector
TransmitPicture Transmits telemetry frames to the control server
 

Package org.haldean.chopper Description

Flies a quadrocopter from an android-based phone. Package has six main components: ChopperStatus maintains updated information on status readings from various sensors, Comm handles text communications with the control server, Guidance handles absolute motor speed, MakePicture captures telemetry from the camera, Navigation handles autopilot routines, and TransmitPicture handles the transmission of telemetry to the control server. These classes are all either Runnables or themselves Threads, and exactly one instance of each should be run at a time.

Task scheduling and inter-thread communication is handled with the Handler class.

Many fields/objects are shared between threads. In almost every case, only a single thread will ever write to a shared field/object, though many may read from that data. Furthermore, many threads are time-sensitive: a delay in execution may result in catastrophic hardware failure. Consequently, a collection of ReentrantLocks is used to ensure that all read/writes of shared data either are uncorrupted and immediate or do not take place at all. Shared data that cannot be interrupted mid-read or write (i.e. the actual reads or write is ultimately accomplished in a single step) usually have no associated lock; shared data that can be interrupted usually do. As a rule, time-sensitive threads that only read from shared data use the tryLock() method; it is often better to use old data than to suspend execution to wait for a lock. Threads that write to a shared field, however, usually use the lock() method to ensure that accurate data is ultimately recorded.

Package Specification

Runs only on an Android-based device
  • Android
